title: Anchor Framework Basics

children.text: Solana is a high-performance blockchain designed for mass adoption. It achieves ~65,000 TPS through a combination of Proof of History (PoH) and Proof of Stake (PoS).

• 400ms block times
• Sub-cent transaction fees
• 65,000+ TPS throughput
• Single global state
Everything on Solana is an account. Accounts store data and SOL. Programs are special accounts marked as executable.
Every account has: a public key (address), lamports (SOL balance), data (byte array), owner (program that controls it), and an executable flag.

title: Program Derived Addresses

children.text: PDAs are deterministic addresses derived from seeds and a program ID. They have no private key, so only the program can sign for them.

A Solana transaction contains one or more instructions. Each instruction specifies a program to call, accounts to pass, and instruction data. Transactions are atomic — all instructions succeed or all fail.

Every instruction consumes compute units (CU). The default limit is 200,000 CU per transaction. You can request up to 1.4M CU with ComputeBudgetProgram. Prioritization fees are paid in micro-lamports per CU.

title: Anchor: Hello World

children.text: Anchor is a framework for Solana programs that handles boilerplate: account validation, discriminators, and serialization. Let's write your first Anchor program.

title: Anchor: PDAs & Seeds

children.text: PDAs in Anchor use the seeds constraint. Anchor automatically derives the bump and validates the address. The bump is stored in the account for future use.
